titleStmt.title: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 128: Documents Relating to Archbishop Cranmer

address.addrLine: Maison Européenne des Sciences de l'Homme et de la Société

msIdentifier.repository: UK, Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, Parker Library

supportDesc.extent: Plusieurs folios reliés constituant un total de 442 pages en papier mesurant 314 mm de haut pour 210 mm de large dont seulement 360 pages sont traitées dans le cadre du projet RePPOL.

abstract.p: MS 128 contains a collection of sixteenth-century documents bound together due to their connections with Thomas Cranmer, Archbishop of Canterbury. The volume contains a collection of accusations against clergy opposed to Cranmer, accounts for the imprisonment and execution of Cranmer, Latimer and Ridley in Oxford (including a request for payment of money still owing) and a biography of Archbishop Cranmer.

Articles against several of the clergy, interrogatories for, and depositions of Dr. John Willoughby, Robert Serles, William Gardiner, Edmund Shethur, Richard Parkhurst, Arthur St. Leger, John Mills, William Hunt, William Cocks, John Thatcher, &c.

langUsage.p: Principalement rédigé en Anglais avec quelques passages en Latin.

projectDesc.p: Notre projet est consacré à la transcription, l’édition critique et l’analyse d’un document exceptionnel : le manuscrit MS 128 conservé à la bibliothèque de Corpus Christi College, Cambridge (à voir sur la plateforme TACT). Il s’agit d’un manuscrit composite d’environ 220 folios qui contient la documentation rassemblée en 1543 sous l’égide de l’Archevêque de Cantorbéry, Thomas Cranmer. Celui-ci, gagné aux idées réformées, est visé par un complot ourdi par des chanoines de sa propre cathédrale (d’où le surnom de Prebendaries Plot) en lien avec des prêtres et des laïcs « conservateurs » du diocèse du Kent. Ces derniers initient un travail de collecte de dénonciations attestant de la radicalité religieuse de Cranmer et de certains de ses clients réformés afin de discréditer l’archevêque de Cantorbéry aux yeux du roi et précipiter sa chute. Cependant, le roi maintient sa faveur à Cranmer mais le charge d’enquêter sur toutes les croyances ou pratiques non conformistes dans son diocèse. L’objectif de cette vaste enquête est encore à élucider. L’archevêque semble saisir cette occasion pour incriminer les clercs et les laïcs conservateurs qui ont participé au Prebendaries Plot : ses agents collectent dénonciations et témoignages de croyances ou pratiques « superstitieuses » ou « papistes » ; mais, le manuscrit renferme également des dénonciations de sacramentaires, d’iconoclastes et d’évangéliques radicaux, qui auraient davantage pu susciter l’indulgence de Cranmer.

Dès lors, le manuscrit MS 128, fruits de ces collectes antinomiques, est une mosaïque double. Mosaïque de documents d’abord, puisqu’il comporte des lettres de dénonciations, des interrogatoires ou encore des mémorandums dont le sens nous échappe en partie ; mais il est aussi une mosaïque de traces des croyances et des pratiques religieuses dans un comté anglais des années 1540. En effet, il renferme plus d’une centaine de témoignages ou dénonciations émanant de clercs et de laïcs des deux sexes et de tout rang. Cette documentation fragmentée révèle l’éclectisme des croyances et des pratiques dans cette Angleterre qui a rompu avec Rome depuis près de dix ans et dans laquelle Henri VIII peine à imposer une quelconque uniformité malgré l’instauration de la Suprématie royale. Ce manuscrit serait-il la trace archivistique des tentatives royales (et de leurs limites) d’imposer une « uniformité religieuse » désirée par Henri VIII depuis le début des années 1530 ?

Jusqu’à présent, plusieurs historiens ont mobilisé partiellement cette source dans le contexte d’études plus larges (Ethan Shagan afin d’explorer l’avancée de la Réforme en Angleterre, Diarmaid MacCulloch pour dresser les portraits des détracteurs de Thomas Cranmer dans la biographie qu’il lui consacre…), mais aucune étude du manuscrit per se n’a été menée et on ne l’a jamais fait dialoguer avec des documents proches (interrogatoires, dénonciations…) pour en dégager les éclairages politiques, religieux ou sociaux qu’il peut apporter sur la période.

Or, le projet RePPOL entend montrer que cette source exceptionnelle permet non seulement d’éclairer les croyances et les pratiques liturgiques populaires souvent inattendues, parfois cocasses, dans un Kent en « transition confessionnelle », mais aussi de saisir la Réforme anglaise comme un phénomène de transformation anthropologique du rapport au religieux, processus qui s’étend sur des plusieurs décennies du XVIe siècle. RePPOL s’inscrit enfin dans le cadre des renouvellements historiographiques récents sur le rôle du peuple dans la production du politique à l’époque moderne, ces témoignages permettant de comprendre le rôle actif que les sujets, y compris les laïcs les plus infimes, ont pu jouer dans les processus de mutations politico-religieuses que connaît l’Angleterre henricienne.

Adoptant une démarche de recherche collaborative et de formation par la recherche, ce projet s'articule en trois temps. La première étape (fin juin 2021-début 2022) vise à transcrire l'intégralité du manuscrit, par une démarche collaborative mobilisant enseignants-chercheurs et étudiants dans le cadre du cours de paléographie moderne. La transcription semi-diplomatique est réalisé via la plateforme de Transcription et d'Annotations de Corpus Textuel (TACT) développée par l'Université de Grenoble. Les images des folios ont été numérisées par la Parker Library et y étaient accessibles selon le cadre interopérable International Image Interoperability Framework (3IF). La seconde étape du travail (2022) est consacrée à l'analyse fine de cette source à la lumière de documents archivistiques de nature similaire. La troisième étape, dont le présent document est l'une des incarnations, est la constitution d'une édition numérique en ligne permettant via balisage en xml-tei l'interrogation du contenu du document par des index.

Our project is devoted to the transcription, critical edition, and analysis of an exceptional document: the manuscript MS 128 held in the library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge (can be viewed on the TACT platform). It is a composite manuscript of about 220 folios that contains the documentation gathered in 1543 under the supervision of the Archbishop of Canterbury, Thomas Cranmer. The latter, won over to the Reformed ideas, was the target of a plot hatched by canons of his own cathedral (hence the nickname of the Prebendaries Plot) in connection with priests and "conservative" laymen of the diocese of Kent. The latter initiated a work of collecting denunciations attesting to the religious radicalism of Cranmer and some of his reformed clients in order to discredit the archbishop of Canterbury in the eyes of the king and precipitate his fall. However, the king maintained his favor to Cranmer but charged him with investigating all non-conformist beliefs or practices in his diocese. The purpose of this vast investigation is yet to be clarified. The archbishop seemed to take the opportunity to incriminate conservative clerics and laymen who had participated in the Prebendaries Plot: his agents collected denunciations and testimonies of "superstitious" or "papist" beliefs or practices; but the manuscript also contained denunciations of sacramentarians, iconoclasts and radical evangelicals, which might have been more likely to elicit Cranmer's leniency.

The manuscript MS 128, fruit of these antinomic collections, is a double mosaic. A mosaic of documents, since it contains letters of denunciation, interrogations and memoranda whose meaning partly escapes us; but it is also a mosaic of traces of religious beliefs and practices in an English county in the 1540's. Indeed, it contains more than a hundred testimonies or denunciations emanating from clerics and laymen of both sexes and of all ranks. This fragmented documentation reveals the eclecticism of beliefs and practices in an England that broke with Rome nearly ten years ago and in which Henry VIII struggled to impose any kind of uniformity despite the establishment of the Royal Supremacy. Could this manuscript be the archival trace of the royal attempts (and their limits) to impose a "religious uniformity" desired by Henry VIII since the early 1530s ?

Several historians have partially mobilized this source in the context of broader studies (Ethan Shagan in order to explore the progress of the Reformation in England, Diarmaid MacCulloch in order to draw up portraits of Thomas Cranmer's detractors in his biography of him... ), but no study of the manuscript per se has been carried out and it has never been put in dialogue with related documents (interrogations, denunciations...) in order to bring out the political, religious or social insights that it can bring to the period.

The RePPOL project intends to show that this exceptional source not only sheds light on the often unexpected, sometimes comical, popular beliefs and liturgical practices in a Kent undergoing a "confessional transition", but also to grasp the English Reformation as a phenomenon of anthropological transformation of the relationship to religion, a process that extends over several decades of the sixteenth century. Finally, RePPOL is part of the recent historiographic renewal on the role of the people in the production of politics in the modern era, as these testimonies allow us to understand the active role that subjects, including the most minute laymen, were able to play in the processes of political and religious mutations that Henrician England experienced.

Adopting a collaborative and training-through-research approach, this project is articulated in three stages. The first stage (end of June 2021-beginning of 2022) aims to transcribe the entire manuscript, through a collaborative approach mobilizing teacher-researchers and students in the context of the modern paleography course. The semi-diplomatic transcription is carried out via the Transcription and Annotation Platform for Textual Corpus (TACT) developed by the University of Grenoble. The images of the folios were digitized by the Parker Library and were accessible there according to the International Image Interoperability Framework (3IF). The second stage of the work (2022) is devoted to fine-grained analysis of this source in light of archival records of a similar nature. The third step, of which the present document is one of the incarnations, is the constitution of an online digital edition allowing via xml-tei tagging the interrogation of the document content by indexes.

editorialDecl.p: Encodage de la structure sémantique du texte en essayant également de rendre compte de la disposition des éléments textuels sur la page. À ceci s'ajoute l'encodage d'entités jugées majeures par l'équipe scientifique, tels les toponymes, les noms de personnes, les rôles et les référents culturels. Enfin l'encodage s'emploie également à rendre compte de la génétique du texte, tentant d'identifier les différentes mains.

normalization.p: Lors de la transcription, les abréviations ont été systématiquement développées, elles ont ensuite été encodées pour être affichées en italituqe conformément au standard de la Folger Shakespeare Library.

div.p: Item he preached than and there. That all the hole faithe of the world, remayned in mary only for the space of iii daies and iii nyghtes
Item that faieth was dede in thappostelles, and in all the world. from the deathe of Christe till his resurrection. and remayned in Virgyn mary hole and only
Item he preached that the sorrowes that she had were greater and more paynefull than Christes But for deathe only

Item he preached this: Christe descended into hell and rose the thirde day. and ascended into heaven. and many moo. with hym. saying this: Multa corpora ascenderunt cum Christo ut prohiberent testimonium. Yea many bodies did ascende with Christ that they might beare witnes of his Ascention
Sir Rauff post clerke. Robert Burgeis. John Colier. John ffurner, Jamys perry
Item the xii daye of August. Anno predictus in the parrishe churche of Ashford he preached. That prayer was not acceptable to god. but in the churche only and no where ellis. Alledging this text
Domus mea domus orationis vocabitur

p.add: Item he pre preched there and than, sayinge, in discoragynge of men from the redynge bible you ffelowes of the new trickery that go up and downe with your testamentes in your handes, I pray you what profet take you by theym,

div.p: Item than and there he preached thus. As Adam was expulsed out of paradise for medlyng with a tree of knouledge. even so be wee: for medling with the scripture of Christ.

He preached at ffaversham in festo dedicationis ecclesie Anno. 1542. That the dedications of materiall churches was instituted for the bishoppes profites. and that he could not see by scripture that they might use any suche fasshons for that purpoas. for they use conjurations / and then they must conjure the devill out of the ground / or out of the lyme and stone / And if so then it wer aswell necessary for every mans house to be consecrate or dedicate
Item admitt (quod he) that the dedication of the same wer laufull. yet the bisshoppes shuld alwaies preache, for that is their office / and other men might and may consecrate them, aswel as they.

Item he saied This sumptuouse adornyng of churches is against thold fashon of the primatyve churche / they had no suche coopes nor chalices nor other Jewelles / nor gildinges. nor payntinges of ymages as wee nowe have / and therefore if I wer curate I wold sell all suche thinges or laye them to pledge to help the poore /

p.add: John Seth. Rich dryland. laurence manby. John hampton. Nich Burdwast Joseph Berverslay. T Transham. John pellayne. Clement Norton. Tho Deve. Tho Okinfelde. Raynolde Becke. William amoore. Ro. ffynes. Rich Sticknay.

p.del: Item at Christmas last there was a generall procession. by the kinges majeste, Mr. Scory preached thies wourdes / Every Contrey hathe a custumme to chuse a patron / as England hath chosen saint George. Scotland saint Andrewe.

thincking rather by intercession of saintz. to obtayne the victory of their ennemyes / But good people (quod he) forasmuche as saintes be circumscript, it is not possible / for that saint that is in the northe to heare the prayer that is made in the southe nor that saint that is in the southe / to heare the praier that is made in the northe

div.p: He preached in Sandwiche the xxiii day of June Anno 1542. That baptyme taketh away but only originall synne,
He preached at Sandwiche the 269 of July Anno 34 domino nostro Reges. That every man syns the passion of Christe: hathe asmuche liberty and free will of as ever Adam had in paradise before his fall

p.add: Item the same tyme & place he preched, that the new precheres with the libertie of the gospel hath caused our lyvynge to be worse than the Turkes. Item he said that zachary & Elizabet his wife kept al the commaundmentes of god, & that it was a light thynge for every man to kepe theym, if he wolde.

div.p: He preached the same day and place That Christ and baptisme did nothing elles but washe awaye our originall synne / and if that any man after baptisme, did fall he must purchace remission of his synnes by penaunce as mary magdalen did /

p.add: Item he preched there that a certen kynge was sicke of a leprocie, & had a vision to go to Jordan to be baptized wasshed, & sholde be hole. And as he was in his good intent goinge thider., he thought that he had as good & swete water in his own cuntray as that was. And so returned backe & wasshed hymselfe therin, but no thynge at al he therby mended. And than he went to Jordan, & so was made hole.

div.p: In a Sermon he compared mannes conscience to a dogge / and said, that if a mans conscience (which he called his dogge) did myslike the sermon,

Biware of thies false precheres, which prech to you new fangelles. wil you knowe how to discerne a true precher from a false. You have a dogge which is your conscience. Whan so ever you shal com to any sermon, aske your dogge what he saith unto it. If he say it be good, than folowe it. But if your dogge barke agaynst it, & say that it is naught
The curate of muche mongeham goyng on procession refuseth and will in no wise syng nor say the lateny in suche maner as all other curates doo
Robert Newyngton of Edgerton resisteth to come to comme to the Sepulcher at the tyme of Eastr withoute their were brede and drinke their, he hath rebuked other that have don it
He hath refused and resisted against making of lightes aboute the rode lofte
He saith that it ys Idolatry to the Sepulture he refuseth to goo a procession. Gilbert Bacheler.
Thomas makeblith Barbour of Canterbury did not bere palme on palme sondaye last past, but rede the bible in procession tyme
On easter daye last past he went into a corner at the resurrection tyme, and went not a procession as other did
Mr. Isaac toke a preiste named Sir Thomas, and put into a seculer mannys apparell, made hym a horsekeper

list.item: Thomas Calcot and other of the

div.p: He saied the xviii day of ffebruarye last past. That allmighty god was neither pleased with fasting nor distcontent with eating.
The iiiith day of marche last past he preachid this Neither almes deades fasting, neither prayer dothe help the soule of man. but faith allonly

The same daye he saied thies wourdes: he that dothe trust to have any help, by the praiers of any p creature or personne, dothe committ Idolatry that ever god made dothe commyt Idolatrye, and dothe make hym an Idoll. whiche is contrary to the commaundement of god,
He inverted thordre of the confiteor (omytting the name of mary and all sainctz. Saying Confiteor deo et vobis & precor vos. orare pro me christi,
he preached the xxviii day of Aprill last past and saied. That god dothe not regarde the prayers but the personnes,

p.add: The vi day of may he said. opon saturday you shal have whitson evyn, you nede not to fast except you wil.

div.p: I will quod he come to my goostely father and shewed to hym I have synned in the vii dedely synnes, and have broken the x commaundementes and myspent my v wittes, and will desire hym of his goostly counseill.

div.note: Heresies detected and the detectours } n
div.p: Serles saide
Christe was nurrished with celestiall mylke, and not materiall
} Thies personnes ar noted to be witnes of the Sermon made at Lenham the day of the Assumption of our Ladye
He saied there is none in heaven but Christ only
Only faithe Justifieth
The supper of the lord quod he
ys not hostia pro peccatis but hostia Laudis
The holly gooste is neither in this place nor that etc.

div.head: Edmond Schethers answer ot the 13 Articles

div.p: To the first : I know not the begynners of thes matters at london but I think that Mr serles talked with doctor london of them as he cam from canter to oxxon And I think also that Mr Williby moved such matters much ther by reson he said that he had spoken with many of the kinges cownsell in it & that he wold take upon him to be the hole setter forth of the matter. After the woordes Mr baker did send for Mr parkhurst Mr gardener & me.
I know none that gave cownsell ther but I think that Mr williby did much of his own hedde
I know not who cousend ther in the matter other wise then as I have said that Mr baker shewd us the book the which my lord of wynchester rede & doctor london took the names of the witnes of the same

I know no grownd thei hadd but I think that the coming of Sir turner & Sir anthony parson & other owt of other dioces in to this: And the resort that was so fare of : to Sir turners sermons: And the subscribing of Sir bland to his articles as it is said: And the reding of sur anthony parson of the bible & other with adding ther expositions to the same was a gret occasion of it
I know not who declared ony grownd ther but I think Mr williby shewd the book & moved the matter much ther
I know no matters ony in london knoweth my lordes grace culpable in but in such articles as master baker willed us to say what we hard we did

I know not the begynner of it in canter but I suspect Mr coxston & Mr gardener by reyso that coxston did use to write all such matters And many articles of the book wer known only to Mr gardener. As for other matters the fame was grete
I know none that the promoter but Mr gardener & williby as towching the books before such tyme that it was subscribed then the witnes wer all of cownsell that Mr williby hadd the book
Mr gardener & williby conferd to gither befor Mr williby receved the book & after such as subscribe talked of the articles sometyme & of other articles as we hard them spoken

I know no grownd but I thinke as I have said in the 4 article above and also bicause the prorses aganst Mr rydley & scory went not forth as against Mr serles & me: Also bycause Joan barnes, gilles barran, bukner (?) & other of when much talking was of, wer not poonisshed & other matters which I remember not that men said wer much borne
I do not know what knowledge other men hadd

I have hard men say many thinges as that my lord did nkow of bukners opynion of Joan barnes opynion: that gilles of barran used the office of a prest being no prest & other thinges which were not reformed but thes thinges manye wer done before I cam in to thes partes & whrin he my lordes grace is culpable it is not in me to say nor I know not what other do know my lord to be culpable in

the last tyme I was at london with Mr baker he hadd me go and se a book of articles that I went to Mr moyle hadd & to show him also as to doctor london the article of sir bland quod missa non est sacrifitium pro peccatis And when I shewd Mr moile the said article he said : alas is then mor articles yet agaynst him he hath to many all redy And by reson it was then night I d(id) only drink with him & he said he wolde helpe to a quietnes asmuch as in h(im?) lay in thes matters & so I departed frome hym. Also mr gardener shewed me that he hadd deliverd certayn articles to Mr thwattes to whome I sent at doctor cokes coming by the advice of Mr gardener to have a bill which thei of s. georges hadd put up to him: to thintent it might be presented to do(ctor) cokes And he sent it me with mo billes which wer presented befor to the said doctor cokes. As for any communycation I never hard them say but that th(ey?) truste we shuld have a quitnes in opinions & that all thing shuld be w(?) I know not with whome other have spoken in thes matters
I know not to whay thinges thei have conduced unto

I know nothing that petit hath done but that he delyverd the book coxston wrot (hym?) (1) & gave it to master baker contrary contrary to his promys maid to Mr gardener & me which told (him?) that it was unperfecte & not proved in many poyntes. Also one night at Mr parkhurstes at supper talking of the sessions of the 6 articles he redd a form or copy of an endightment having no mans name nor I know not wh(en?) he red it but only to shew (as I think) a forme of such endightmentes a(s?) wer used at the 6 articles
I know no man that ever entended ony other thing then to have a un(ity?) & quietnes in opinions and all contention to cease

I can not say of other men but after that Mr baker willed me to note the che- fist berers & authors of thes new opynions we thowght I could do no (-??) but write such thinges as I harde And therfor I can say little in this matter but as I se my writing to put in me in remembrans.

Whether I spake of ony such thinge at charing I can not tell byt I remember that at Mr parkurstes table in canter as one spake of preaching in thanet (I said) (as it is trew in dede) that I was never ther syns I cam in to kent: but bicause I hard the cowntrey so gretly commended I said I longged to goe thither: upon which woordes Mr mylles (I think) said whi let us: Mr garde(ner) I, mr serles and yow go thither one day And bicause ther be viii churches (-?) us prech 2 sermons a peice & so in all the churches in one day And afte(r) we will make myrry ther a bowt a day or 2 & come home agayn her is all the intent & prorses I know was hadd in the same not I never hard mor of it. Or if I spake of it at charing it was by reson that the vicar of charing desired me to prech at his benefice ther :that I told him what we talked of thanet one day, but I do not well remember

div.head: Articles send to me Richard parkehurste to make A Awnsswere unto/by my lord off Caunterbury

note.hi: Item whyther tharchBysshop dyd of consystory that the kynges plesure was to have III prechers of the new lernyng & III of tholde Thys Aw ys Awnssweryd to yn the Article wher my lord dyd Rebuke mr Serlys for prechyng.

div.p: In primis whether they presented unto Tharchbysshopp off Caunterbury the selfsame Articles that be conteyned yn the Boke of complaynt. or whether be more or ffewer off or Sum Altered by addycys off woordes To thys y Awnsswere. I had never the Boke off complaynt yn my handes nor dyd here Thorowly here then Red and but very ffew of them / same soych as mr sayntleger & I dyd put up to my lordes grace / There ys yn the Boke off complaynt sum Addycys of woordes mo then mr Sayntleger & I dyd put up to my lord

Item whether the wytnes browght yn. dyd prove al the Seyde Articles. To thys I sey that I have no knolege whether the wytneses dyd prove the seyde Articles or no. for y dyd never se the Booke off Examynacyon
Item whether they lefte owte thre Articles that be for wer presented To thys y sey that I was not of knolege what they wer that were lefte owte nether yete why nor wherefore the were lefte owte
Item whether Tharchebysshopp of Caunterbury dyd Rebuke Serlys for that he preched that ymages myght be permytted yn the Churche as representors off Saynttes and not ydollys

To thys y sey that my lordes grace dyd challenge mr Serelys for prechyng but I do not Remembre that hys grace dyd Rebuke or chalenge the seyde mr Serelys for that he preched that ymagys myght be permytted yn the Church as repre- sentors off Saynttes. thys I remembre well that my lordes grace Asked off mr Serelys seyng / Evid quid est Idolum. mr Serelys Awnsswered & seyd. Idolum est nichyll / then seyd my lord / after the Greke ydolum & ymago ar all one. then Seyde mr Gardener I cannot tel I kno not the Greke. But that ys Idolum to when honor ys Gevyn wych sholde be gevyn to cryst // After that my lord seyde that he had put yn III prechers off the oolde lernyng & III of the new. Then seyde mr Gardener that ys a mene to set A dyvysyon. then my lordes grace seyde as I remebre now that hyt was the kynges plesure or the kynge woolde have hyt so / for the Second parte that my lordes grace shold so sey yn the Consystory. Threwly I was not there where for y can sey nothyng to that

that all the faith of the world remained in Mary only for 3 days and 3 nights from the death of Christ till his Resurrection, and her sorrows were more painful than Christ's but for death only; that when Christ ascended into Heaven many ascended with him, to bear witness of it. (Witnesses, Sir Rauff Post, clk., Robert Burges, John Colier, John Furner, Jas. Perry.) On 12 Aug. he preached in the parish ch. of Ashford that prayer was not acceptable to God but in the church only, alleging the text Domus mea domus orationis rocabitur; he also discouraged men from reading the Bible, saying "You fellows of the new trickery that go up and down with your Testaments in your hands, I pray you what profit take you by them?" (fn. 27) He also said, as Adam was expelled from Paradise for meddling with a tree of knowledge. "even so we for meddling with the Scripture of Christ."

thinking rather by intercession of Saints to obtain the victory of their enemies. But, good people, quod he, for as much as Saints be circumscript, it is not possible for that Saint that is in the North to hear the prayer that is made in the South, nor that Saint that is in the South to hear the prayer that is made in the North."] (fn. 29)
Most of the above sayings of Scory are noted by Cranmer in the margin as "Error," "slanderous" or "seditious."

div.head: 20 Sept. 1543.Shether.
div.p: He preached at Sandwich, 23 June 1542 that Baptism takes away only original sin (Cr. "Heresy"); and on the 29 July 34 Hen. VIII. that every man since the Passion of Christ has as much free will as Adam had in Paradise (Cr. "Error"); also that the new preachers with the liberty of the Gospel have caused our living to be worse than the Turks; that Zachary and Elizabeth his wife kept all the commandments, and that it was a light thing for every man to keep them if he would; that if a man sinned after baptism he must purchase remission by penance like Mary Magdalen; also of a king that had a leprosy and had a vision to go to Jordan to wash and be made whole; but in going he thought the well waters of his own country would be as good and turned back and washed in them, but, not being cured, went to Jordan and so was made whole. He compared a man's conscience to a dog, and said "Beware of these false preachers, which preach to you new fangells. Will you know how to discern a true preacher from a false? You have a dog, which is your conscience. Whensoever you shall come to any sermon ask your dog what he saith unto it. If he say it be good, then follow it; but if your dog bark against it and say that it is naught,

div.head: The curate of Much Mongeam, 24 Sept., 1543.
div.p: In going on procession he will sing no litany.

div.head: Rob. Newington, 24 Sept. 1543.
div.p: Refuses to come to the Sepulchre at Easter "unless there were bread and drink there," and has rebuked others for doing it. "He hath refused and resisted against making of lights about the rood loft;" says "it is idolatry to the Sepulture," and refuses to go in procession.

div.head: Thos. Makeblyth of Canterbury, barber, 26 Sept. 1543.
div.p: Did not bear palm last Palm Sunday, but read the Bible in procession time. On Easter day he went into a corner at the Resurrection time and went not a procession as others did. Mr. Isaac took a priest named Sir Thomas, put him in secular apparel and made him a horsekeeper.

div.head: 21 Sept.
div.p: Hugh Cooper of Tenterden said, 18 Feb. last, that God was neither pleased with fasting nor discontent with eating. On the 4 March last he preached that neither alms deeds, fasting, nor prayer did help the soul, but faith only; also that whoever trusted to have help by the prayers of any person that ever God made committed idolatry. He inverted the order of the Confiteor, omitting the name of Mary and All Saints. He preached 28 April that God did not regard the prayers but the persons. Added by Cr. :On the 6 May he said "On Saturday you shall have Whitsun Even. You need not to fast except you will."

div.head: 21 Sept. 1543.
div.p: Archebolde of Faversham. "I will, quod he, come to my ghostly father and show to him I have sinned in the 7 deadly sins and have broken the 10 commandments, and misspent my 5 wits and will desire him of his ghostly counsel."
ii. A list of heresies detected and the detectors.

div.head: 25 Sept. 1543.Serles.
div.p: "Christ was nourished with celestial milk and not material." Nine witnesses named who heard the sermon at Leneham, the day of the Assumption of Our Lady. "

div.head: Die Ascensionis Domini, 1541.
div.p: "Scory. "He said there was none in heaven but Christ only." Four witnessesone of them is Shether. (2.)

div.head: In Lent 1541.
div.p: "Only faith justifieth" : Ws., Gardiner, Wm. Cockes. (3.) "The Supper of the Lord, quod he, is not hostia pro peccatis but hostia laudis. Ws., Parkhurst, Gardiner, Hunt, Milles.

div.head: In Die Pentecostes ultimo.
div.p: Drumme. "The Holy Ghost is neither in this place nor that, &c." Ws., Cyriack Petit, W. Hunt, Shether.
